p: Asherman syndrome (AS) is characterized by severe damage of the endometrium due to curettage and/or endometritis [ 1]. Approximately 25â€“30% of infertile women suffer from AS, which represents the most common cause of uterine infertility [ 2]. The traditional treatment for AS is the transcervical resection of adhesion by hysteroscopy followed by the placement of an intrauterine device, Foley catheter or biomaterials to prevent recurrent intrauterine adhesions (IUA) [ 3, 4] and hormonal therapy to regenerate the endometrium [ 5]. However, in severe cases, the incidence of recurrent IUA was reported to be as high as 62.5% [ 6]. This endometrial fibrosis impedes embryo implantation [ 7]. Therefore, preventing IUA recurrence and endometrial scarring are considered key factors that affect therapeutic outcomes [ 8].
